text:
Hey folks! *Can you help me think through something*?
I’ve been thinking about why some content marketing programmes fail to make meaningful contributions to a business, and I’ve boiled it down to the interplay between:
- findability (aka: content is shared across channels used by target customers) and -
- relevance (aka: content is what target customers need)

So in the post-it matrix below,
• High findability, low relevance → content brings traffic and zero conversions because the wrong audiences find it 
• High relevance, low findability → content brings a fraction of the conversions it could have because it’s not distributed across the right channels 
• Low findability, low relevance → somebody’s going to get fired
• High findability, high relevance → :moneybag: :chart_with_upwards_trend: :tada:
What do you think about this framework? Do you see any obvious holes or things I should be considering?
And how does it map to your experiences in content marketing?

Thank you :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Hey folks!
Can you help me think through something

?
I’ve been thinking about why some content marketing programmes fail to make meaningful contributions to a business, and I’ve boiled it down to the interplay between:
- findability (aka: content is shared across channels used by target customers) and -
- relevance (aka: content is what target customers need)

So in the post-it matrix below,
High findability, low relevance → content brings traffic and zero conversions because the wrong audiences find it
High relevance, low findability → content brings a fraction of the conversions it could have because it’s not distributed across the right channels
Low findability, low relevance → somebody’s going to get fired
High findability, high relevance →

What do you think about this framework? Do you see any obvious holes or things I should be considering?
And how does it map to your experiences in content marketing?

Thank you

text:
<@U01MW6DPU72> you have an agency, if I’m not wrong. Say a client of yours comes and finds themselves in the top left or the bottom right — what would YOU suggest they do next?
<@URLKJLWKS> to me high findability = easily found/distributed and low relevance = the people who find it are not the right fit. This is the typical quadrant where somebody ranks for a million keywords that bring unqualified people to a website. Is it clearer or do I have to consider rewording something [I’m not in love with ‘findability’ but it’s hard to use ‘distribution’ in relation to low/high]?

text: Aha, got it now. It's the mix between channels and target persons (we're also debating this in our team in terms of "is it too broad, is it too narrow?"). In that case, yes, it's clear. I was thinking "discoverability" as well when I was replying, but I would say your "findability" sounds better.  The "relevance" one confused me at first, as a word per se, as it's more of the potential for that content to convert the right users — are we attracting MQLs and SQLs or people we don't want as customers? So we have a lot of readers/traffic, but not the ones we want/need. Is that right?

elements.text: Aha, got it now. It's the mix between channels and target persons (we're also debating this in our team in terms of "is it too broad, is it too narrow?"). So we have a lot of readers/traffic, but not the ones we want/need. Is that right?

text: I see now how ‘relevance’ can be misleading—but yes, the relevance is in relation to an ideal customer (precisely what you said—content is almost always relevant to… someone!, but they may not be MQLs or PQLs or whatever we want to call them)

text:
Here's what Andy says from Content Chemistry:

*If your conversion rate is more than 2% but traffic is low:*

- Write more SEO blog posts
- Guest posts
- List posts

*If bounce rate is low and people don't visit many pages:*

- Write how-to pages
- Add more internal links
- Collaborate with influencers
- Use a more personal tone

*If your conversion rate is low:*

- Publish more stories about your brand
- Show evidence of the value of your services (case studies)
- Publish content that answers common sales questions
- Guide visitors from blog to marketing pages
- Publish articles for specific prospects

- Guide visitors from blog to marketing pages
- Publish articles for specific prospects

text: This might be implied, but is this chart focused on content where your goal is a conversion? I think like most things in marketing, it depends. For example, if I have a thought leadership post that brings in traffic, starts conversations, and acquires links but no conversions, is is "bad content"? No, because it's doing other great things and meeting other goals. Similar with the low traffic / high conversion category - that could be a piece of content we created for sales enablement that applies to a much smaller portion of the funnel. My main point being, I think content can have other goals than pure conversions and still serve an important purpose. Maybe the most important part is to simply have a goal in mind. Would love to hear others' thoughts here. :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: This might be implied, but is this chart focused on content where your goal is a conversion? I think like most things in marketing, it depends. No, because it's doing other great things and meeting other goals. Similar with the low traffic / high conversion category - that could be a piece of content we created for sales enablement that applies to a much smaller portion of the funnel. My main point being, I think content can have other goals than pure conversions and still serve an important purpose. Maybe the most important part is to simply have a goal in mind. Would love to hear others' thoughts here.

text:
<@U017WRJTKF1> I like this as a kind of mapped manifestation of the two sides of content that I've always harped on about: creation and distribution. It's not a perfect overlap, but pretty close!

There's possibly a Z axis to consider: production capacity. You could have High Rel and Find but if you're posting once per month it could also leave conversions on the table... but the simplicity of a 2x2 is usually a sweet spot for explaining to non-experts.

Production can also be split into 2x2 as Studio x operations, which then also maps pretty close to Creation x Distribution and Relevance x Findability.

text: :thinking_face:

<@U017WRJTKF1> put it like this for the top left — "to me high findability = easily found/distributed and low relevance = the people who find it are not the right fit." So I wouldn't say that thought leadership is there, as it's not a matter of "not the right readers", right? What do you think? Love the "Quadrant of sadness" bit!
